title: 107_s3154
content: Section 1 amends the Internal Revenue Code to require fuel transfers to registered terminals or refineries to be done by pipeline or vessel. It also introduces a civil penalty for carrying taxable fuels by nonregistered pipelines or vessels. If taxable fuel is willfully carried by an unregistered pipeline or vessel, the operator must pay a penalty in addition to the tax. The penalty amount is $10,000 per violation, with increases for multiple violations. Joint and several liability applies for penalties imposed under this section. If a penalty is imposed on a business entity, individuals involved in the act leading to the penalty are jointly liable. The parent corporation of an affiliated group is also jointly liable for the penalty. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. Section 6717 addresses carrying taxable fuels by nonregistered pipelines or vessels, with amendments effective on January 1, 2003. Additionally, returns must be filed electronically. The IRS requires electronic filing of returns for operators with more than 25 fuel transactions per month and individuals with at least 25 vehicles for tracking purposes. The Secretary of the Treasury will specify the electronic filing format. The IRS mandates electronic filing of returns for operators with over 25 fuel transactions monthly and individuals with a minimum of 25 vehicles. The Secretary of the Treasury will define the electronic filing format. Returns under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code must be filed within 30 or 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendment applies to returns due after the Secretary describes the filing format. SEC. 3 amends the definition of diesel fuel for tax purposes to include any liquid (other than gasoline) sold, regardless of its suitability for use. The amendment takes effect upon enactment. SEC. 4 introduces a civil penalty for refusal of entry under the Internal Revenue Code. In addition to any criminal penalty, a person refusing entry or actions authorized by the Secretary for transporting untaxed fuel mixtures or dyed diesel for taxable use shall pay a $1,000 penalty. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include a civil penalty for such refusals. The text chunk discusses penalties for refusal to permit actions authorized by the Secretary, including a $1,000 penalty for transporting untaxed fuel mixtures or dyed diesel for taxable use. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code also include a civil penalty for such refusals. The amendments made by this section involve the display of registration on vessels transporting fuel and treating untaxed adulterated fuel mixtures as dyed fuels under penalty provisions, effective January 1, 2003. Section 6715(c)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include dyed diesel fuel, kerosene chemically altered to remove dye, or any adulterated fuel mixture not previously taxed. This amendment takes effect upon enactment of the Act. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to impose tax on taxable fuel at the time of entry if the importer is not registered, with immediate jeopardy assessment and enforcement provisions. The amendment enforces detention of fuel and vehicles/vessels for non-compliance with filing a bond, with provisions for sale of fuel if bond not filed within 5 days. Effective upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 8. MODIFICATIONS OF TAX ON USE OF CERTAIN VEHICLES. The tax rate in section 4481(a) of the Internal Revenue Code is increased from $550 to $600. Section 4481(c) is amended to prorate tax for destroyed or stolen vehicles not used in the taxable period. The tax rate in section 4481(a) of the Internal Revenue Code is increased to $600. A highway motor vehicle is considered destroyed if it is damaged to the extent that it is not economical to rebuild. Display of tax certificate on the vehicle is required by October 1 for each taxable period. Section 6156 of the Internal Revenue Code, regarding installment payment of tax on highway motor vehicles, is repealed. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable periods starting after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. ADDITIONAL RULES REGARDING INSPECTIONS OF RECORDS. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include providing copies of records upon request and allowing inspection by other enforcement agencies for certain tax-related information. The effective date for these amendments is upon the enactment of the Act. SEC. 10 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for on-site inspection of records to identify individuals involved in fuel transactions. The effective date for these amendments is upon the enactment of the Act. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection regarding penalties for the taxable use of dyed diesel fuel. The penalty under section 6715 cannot be appealed if dye is found in diesel fuel used on the highway, unless there is fraud or mistake in analysis or calculation. These amendments take effect upon the enactment of the Act.
